# History of Costa Rica

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

The first natives in Costa Rica were hunters and gatherers, and Costa Rica
served as an "Intermediate Region" between Mesoamerican and Andean native
cultures.

In 1502, [Christopher Columbus](/wiki/Christopher_Columbus "Christopher
Columbus") made landfall in Costa Rica. Soon after, his forces overcame the
[indigenous people](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_Costa_Rica "Indigenous peoples
of Costa Rica"). He incorporated the territory into the [Captaincy General of
Guatemala](/wiki/Captaincy_General_of_Guatemala "Captaincy General of
Guatemala") as a province of [New Spain](/wiki/New_Spain "New Spain") in 1524.
For the next 300 years, Costa Rica was a colony of Spain. As a result, Costa
Rica's culture has been greatly influenced by the culture of Spain.[1] During
this period, Costa Rica remained sparsely developed and impoverished.

Following the [Mexican War of Independence](/wiki/Mexican_War_of_Independence
"Mexican War of Independence") (1810–1821), Costa Rica became part of the
independent [Mexican Empire](/wiki/First_Mexican_Empire "First Mexican
Empire") in 1821. Subsequently, Costa Rica was part of the [Federal Republic
of Central America](/wiki/Federal_Republic_of_Central_America "Federal
Republic of Central America") in 1823, before gaining full independence in
1838. Its economy struggled due to lack of connections with European
suppliers. In 1856, Costa Rica resisted [American](/wiki/Americans
"Americans") settlers from mounting a take-over of the government.

After 1869, Costa Rica established a democratic government.[1]

After the [Costa Rican Civil War](/wiki/Costa_Rican_Civil_War "Costa Rican
Civil War") in 1948, the government drafted a new
[constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution"), guaranteeing universal
suffrage and the dismantling of the military. Today, Costa Rica is a democracy
that relies on [technology](/wiki/Technology "Technology") and [eco-
tourism](/wiki/Eco-tourism "Eco-tourism") for its economy. Although
[poverty](/wiki/Poverty "Poverty") has declined since the turn of the 21st
century, economic problems still exist. Costa Rica is facing problems of
[underemployment](/wiki/Underemployment "Underemployment"), foreign and
internal debt, and a trade deficiency.[1]

## Pre-Columbian Costa
Rica[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Costa_Rica&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Pre-Columbian Costa Rica")]

Main article: [Pre-Columbian history of Costa Rica](/wiki/Pre-
Columbian_history_of_Costa_Rica "Pre-Columbian history of Costa Rica")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Ceramicas_Nicoya.jpg/300px-
Ceramicas_Nicoya.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ceramicas_Nicoya.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ceramicas_Nicoya.jpg "Enlarge")

Pre-Columbian Ceramics from Nicoya, Costa Rica

In [Pre-Columbian](/wiki/Pre-Columbian "Pre-Columbian") times, the [Native
Americans](/wiki/Native_American_\(Americas\) "Native American \(Americas\)")
in what is now [Costa Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica "Costa Rica") were part of a
cultural complex known as the "Intermediate Area," between the
[Mesoamerican](/wiki/Mesoamerican "Mesoamerican") and [Andean](/wiki/Andean
"Andean") cultural regions.[2]

The northwest of the country, the [Nicoya Peninsula](/wiki/Nicoya_Peninsula
"Nicoya Peninsula"), was the southernmost point of [Nahuatl](/wiki/Nahuatl
"Nahuatl") cultural influence when the [Spanish](/wiki/Spain "Spain")
conquerors ([conquistadores](/wiki/Conquistadores "Conquistadores")) came in
the sixteenth century. The central and southern portions of the country had
[Chibcha](/wiki/Chibcha "Chibcha") influences. The indigenous people have
influenced modern Costa Rican culture to a relatively small degree. In the
years soon after European encounter, many of the people died due to
[infectious diseases](/wiki/Infectious_diseases "Infectious diseases"), such
as [measles](/wiki/Measles "Measles") and [smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox
"Smallpox"), which were endemic among the Europeans but to which they had no
immunity.[3]

### Hunter-gatherers (10,000–2,000
BC)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Costa_Rica&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Hunter-gatherers \(10,000–2,000 BC\)")]

The oldest evidence of human occupation in [Costa Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica
"Costa Rica") is associated with the arrival of groups of hunter-gatherers
about 10,000 to 7,000 years [BC](/wiki/Anno_Domini "Anno Domini"), with
ancient archaeological evidence (stone tool making) located in the [Turrialba
Valley](/wiki/Turrialba,_Costa_Rica "Turrialba, Costa Rica"), at sites called
Guardiria and Florence, with matching quarry and workshop areas with presence
of type [clovis spearheads](/wiki/Clovis_culture "Clovis culture") and South
American inspired [arrows](/wiki/Arrow "Arrow"). All this suggests the
possibility that in this area two different cultures coexisted.

The people of this era were nomadic. They were organized in family-based bands
of about 20 to 30 members. Their usual prey animals were called megafauna,
such as giant [armadillos](/wiki/Armadillo "Armadillo") and
[sloths](/wiki/Sloth "Sloth"), [mastodons](/wiki/Mastodons "Mastodons"), etc.
These became extinct about 8,000 years before the modern era. The first
settlers had to adapt to hunting smaller animals and develop appropriate
strategies to adjust to the new conditions.

## Spanish
colonization[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Costa_Rica&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Spanish colonization")]

The colonial period began when [Christopher
Columbus](/wiki/Christopher_Columbus "Christopher Columbus") reached the
eastern coast of Costa Rica on his [fourth
voyage](/wiki/Voyages_of_Christopher_Columbus "Voyages of Christopher
Columbus") on September 18, 1502. Numerous subsequent Spanish expeditions
followed, eventually leading to the first Spanish colony in Costa Rica, Villa
Bruselas founded in 1524.[4]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Pablo_Presbere_Album_de_Figueroa_%281%29.jpg/220px-
Pablo_Presbere_Album_de_Figueroa_%281%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pablo_Presbere_Album_de_Figueroa_\(1\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Pablo_Presbere_Album_de_Figueroa_\(1\).jpg "Enlarge")

Violent uprising of Indians in Talamanca region, 1709

During most of the colonial period, Costa Rica was the southernmost province
of the [Captaincy General of Guatemala](/wiki/Captaincy_General_of_Guatemala
"Captaincy General of Guatemala"), which was nominally part of the
[Viceroyalty of New Spain](/wiki/New_Spain "New Spain") (i.e.,
[Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico")). In practice it operated as a largely
autonomous entity within the [Spanish Empire](/wiki/Spanish_Empire "Spanish
Empire"). Costa Rica's distance from the capital in
[Guatemala](/wiki/Guatemala "Guatemala"), its legal prohibition under Spanish
law against trading with its southern neighbors in [Panama](/wiki/Panama
"Panama"), then part of the [Viceroyalty of New
Granada](/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_New_Granada "Viceroyalty of New Granada") (i.e.,
[Colombia](/wiki/Colombia "Colombia")), and the lack of resources such as
[gold](/wiki/Gold "Gold") and [silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver"), resulted in
Costa Rica attracting few inhabitants. It was a poor, isolated, and sparsely
inhabited region within the Spanish Empire.[5] a Spanish governor in 1719
described Costa Rica as "the poorest and most miserable Spanish colony in all
America." [6]

The area suffered a lack of indigenous population available for [forced
labor](/wiki/Encomienda "Encomienda"), which meant that most of the Costa
Rican settlers had to work their own land. This prevented the establishment of
large _[haciendas](/wiki/Hacienda "Hacienda")_. For all these reasons Costa
Rica was by and large unappreciated and overlooked by the [Spanish
Crown](/wiki/Habsburg_Spain "Habsburg Spain") and left to develop on its own.
The small landowners' relative poverty, the lack of a large indigenous labor
force, the population's ethnic and linguistic homogeneity, and Costa Rica's
isolation from the Spanish colonial centers in Mexico and the Andes, all
contributed to the development of an autonomous and individualistic agrarian
society. Even the Governor had to farm his own crops and tend to his own
garden due to his poverty.[7][_[disputed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Disputed_statement
"Wikipedia:Disputed statement") –
[discuss](/wiki/Talk:History_of_Costa_Rica#Disputed_Statement "Talk:History of
Costa Rica")_]

## Independence from
Spain[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Costa_Rica&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Independence from Spain")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Castro_Madriz.JPG/190px-
Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Castro_Madriz.JPG)](/wiki/File:Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Castro_Madriz.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Castro_Madriz.JPG "Enlarge")

[José María Castro Madriz](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Castro_Madriz "José
María Castro Madriz") formally declared Costa Rica as independent from the
[Federal Republic of Central
America](/wiki/Federal_Republic_of_Central_America "Federal Republic of
Central America") in 1848.

In the early 19th century, [Napoleon](/wiki/Napoleon_I "Napoleon I")'s
occupation of Spain led to the outbreak of revolts all across Spanish America.
In New Spain, all of the fighting by those seeking independence was done in
the center of that area from 1810 to 1821, what today is central Mexico. Once
the Viceroy was defeated in the capital city—today Mexico City—in 1821, the
news of independence was sent to all the territories of New Spain, including
the Intendencies of the former Captaincy of Guatemala. Costa Rica joined the
other Central American Intendancies in a joint declaration of independence
from Spain, the 1821 Act of Independence.

On October 13, 1821 the documents arrived at Cartago, and an emergency meeting
was called upon by Governor Juan Manuel de Cañas. There were many ideas on
what to do upon gaining independence, such as joining Mexico, joining
Guatemala or Nueva Granada (today Colombia). A group was declared (Junta de
Legados), which created the temporary Junta Gubernativa Superior. Meanwhile,
"the clouds clear up" ("Mientras se aclaraban los nublados del día"), was a
famous phrase of the events of the day.

Independence from Spain was acknowledged and ratified on October 29, 1821 by
the colonial authorities. It was then ratified in the cities of San José on
November 1, 1821, at Cartago on November 3rd, 1821, at Heredia on November 11,
1821, and Alajuela on November 25th, 1821.[8]

After the declaration of independence, the New Spain parliament intended to
establish a commonwealth whereby the King of Spain, Ferdinand VII, would also
be Emperor of New Spain, but in which both countries were to be governed by
separate laws and with their own legislative offices. Should the king refuse
the position, the law provided for a member of the [House of
Bourbon](/wiki/House_of_Bourbon "House of Bourbon") to accede to the New Spain
throne. Ferdinand VII did not recognize the colony's independence and said
that Spain would not allow any other European prince to take the throne of New
Spain.

By request of Parliament, the president of the regency, Agustín de Iturbide,
was proclaimed emperor of New Spain, which was renamed as Mexico. The Mexican
Empire was the official name given to this monarchical regime from 1821 to
1823. The territory of the Mexican Empire included the continental
intendancies and provinces of New Spain proper (including those of the former
Captaincy General of Guatemala) (See: History of Central America).

## United Provinces of Central
America[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Costa_Rica&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: United Provinces of Central America")]

In 1823, a revolution in Mexico ousted Emperor [Agustín de
Iturbide](/wiki/Agust%C3%ADn_de_Iturbide "Agustín de Iturbide"). A new Mexican
congress voted to allow the Central American Intendancies to decide their own
fate. That year, the [United Provinces of Central
America](/wiki/United_Provinces_of_Central_America "United Provinces of
Central America") was formed of the five Central American Intendancies under
General [Manuel José Arce](/wiki/Manuel_Jos%C3%A9_Arce "Manuel José Arce").
The Intendancies took the new name of States. The United Provinces federation,
not strongly united to begin with, rapidly disintegrated under the pressures
of intra-provincial rivalries.

Following full independence in 1838, Costa Rica had no regular trade routes
established to export their [coffee](/wiki/Coffee "Coffee") to European
markets. They had problems with lack of infrastructure producing problems in
transportation: the coffee-growing areas were mainly in the Central Valley and
had access only to the port of [Puntarenas](/wiki/Puntarenas "Puntarenas") on
the Pacific Coast. Before the [Panama Canal](/wiki/Panama_Canal "Panama
Canal") was opened, ships from Europe had to sail around [Cape
Horn](/wiki/Cape_Horn "Cape Horn") in order to get to the Pacific Coast. In
1843, the country established a trade route to Europe with the help of
[William Le Lacheur](/wiki/William_Le_Lacheur "William Le Lacheur"), a
[Guernsey](/wiki/Guernsey "Guernsey") merchant and shipowner.

In 1856, [William Walker](/wiki/William_Walker_\(filibuster\) "William Walker
\(filibuster\)"), an American [filibuster](/wiki/Filibuster_\(military\)
"Filibuster \(military\)"), began incursions into Central America. After
landing in [Nicaragua](/wiki/Nicaragua "Nicaragua"), he proclaimed himself as
president of Nicaragua and re-instated [slavery](/wiki/Slavery "Slavery"),
which had been abolished.[9] He intended to expand into Costa Rica and after
he entered that territory, the country declared
[war](/wiki/Campaign_of_1856%E2%80%931857 "Campaign of 1856–1857") against his
forces. Led by Commander in Chief of the Army of Costa Rica, President [Juan
Rafael Mora Porras](/wiki/Juan_Rafael_Mora_Porras "Juan Rafael Mora Porras"),
the filibusters were defeated and forced out of the country. Costa Rican
forces followed the filibusters into [Rivas, Nicaragua](/wiki/Rivas,_Nicaragua
"Rivas, Nicaragua"), where in a final battle, William Walker and his forces
were finally pushed back. [Juan Santamaría](/wiki/Juan_Santamar%C3%ADa "Juan
Santamaría"), a drummer boy from [Alajuela](/wiki/Alajuela "Alajuela") who
lost his life torching the filibusters' stronghold, was killed in this final
battle. He is today remembered as a national hero.[10]

##
Democracy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_Costa_Rica&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Democracy")]

An era of peaceful democracy in Costa Rica began in 1869 with elections. Costa
Rica has avoided much of the violence that has plagued [Central
America](/wiki/Central_America "Central America"). Since the late nineteenth
century, only two brief periods of violence have marred its democratic
development. In 1917–19, [Federico Tinoco
Granados](/wiki/Federico_Tinoco_Granados "Federico Tinoco Granados") ruled as
a [dictator](/wiki/Dictator "Dictator").

In 1948, [José Figueres Ferrer](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Figueres_Ferrer "José Figueres
Ferrer") led an armed uprising in the wake of a disputed presidential
election. "With more than 2,000 dead, the 44-day [Costa Rican Civil
War](/wiki/Costa_Rican_Civil_War "Costa Rican Civil War") resulting from this
uprising was the bloodiest event in twentieth-century Costa Rican
history."[11] The victorious [junta](/wiki/Military_junta "Military junta")
drafted a constitution guaranteeing free elections with universal suffrage and
the abolition of the military. Figueres became a national hero, winning the
first election under the new constitution in 1953. Since then Costa Rica has
been one of the few democracies to operate without a standing army.[12] The
nation has held 16 successive presidential elections, all peaceful, [the
latest being in 2014](/wiki/Costa_Rican_general_election,_2014 "Costa Rican
general election, 2014").

Costa Rica's economy went under a transformation in 1978. The country went
from being "an economic development success story" to entering a severe socio-
economic crisis. Costa Rica relied on the exportation of
[bananas](/wiki/Bananas "Bananas") and coffee. In 1978, coffee prices dropped,
and its revenues declined. In 1979, the price of oil, a main imported item,
increased sharply and rapidly, plunging the country into crisis. In order to
help improve the economy, President Rodrigo Carazo continued to borrow money
internationally. In return, this led the country to be more in
[debt](/wiki/National_debt "National debt").[13]

Once a largely agricultural country, Costa Rica has transformed to relying on
technology industry and services, and [eco-tourism](/wiki/Eco-tourism "Eco-
tourism"). Costa Rica's major source of export income is technology based.
Microsoft, Motorola, Intel and other technology-related firms have established
operations in Costa Rica. Local companies create and export
[software](/wiki/Software "Software") as well as other computer-related
products. Tourism is growing at an accelerated pace, and many believe that
income from this tourism may soon become the major contributor to the nation's
GDP. Traditional agriculture, particularly coffee and bananas, continues to be
an important part of Costa Rica's exports.

nq_3344_9.Answer Analysis: The answer is October 29, 1821, which is the date Costa Rica gained independence from Spain.

nq_3344_9.Key Information Matching: The document directly mentions the date of independence from Spain, which is the key information required by the query.
nq_3344_9.Can the Document Answer the Query: Yes, the document contains the exact date when Costa Rica gained independence from Spain.
nq_3344_9.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: Yes, the document provides additional context about the process and events leading up to the declaration of independence.
nq_3344_9.Explanation: The document is directly relevant to the query as it contains the specific date of Costa Rica's independence from Spain and provides additional historical context that enhances understanding of the event.
